PAGEINFO.instructions_body:
Sort these pictures of features and parts of the Sun by temperature.

Each of the small pictures on the left shows some part of the Sun (such as the core or photosphere or corona) or some kind of solar feature (like sunspots or prominences). The pictures show various size features, from a few thousand miles across (such as sunspots) to more than a million miles (for example, the corona).

Decide how hot you think each part or feature is. Then drag the small picture of that feature or part into the area on the right with the matching temperature range.

If you don't know how hot something is, take a guess! Hints will help you discover which places and features are the hottest.

Have you tried the other level of the Sun Sorting Game yet? Click the Choose Level button to try sorting photos of the Sun into Solar Max and Solar Min groups.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Chromosphere
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: Temperatures in the chromosphere range between about 3,500° to 35,000° Celsius (roughly 6,400° to 63,000° Fahrenheit). In most of the chromosphere, the temperature is a few tens of thousands of degrees. The chromosphere is the lower part of the Sun's atmosphere. Surprisingly, most of the chromosphere is hotter than the "surface" of the Sun (called the photosphere).
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: The chromosphere is the lower part of the Sun's atmosphere. Although most of the chromosphere is hotter than the "surface" of the Sun (called the photosphere), this region is not quite as hot as the corona (the Sun's upper atmosphere) above it.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseTitle: Not exactly, though you are partly right.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: Although temperatures in some parts of the chromosphere are as low as 3,500° Celsius (6,400° Fahrenheit), most of the chromosphere is quite a bit hotter. The chromosphere is the lower part of the Sun's atmosphere.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Sunspots
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: Sunspots have temperatures between 3,000-4,500° Celsius (5,400-8,100° Fahrenheit). Sunspots look darker than the rest of the "surface" of the Sun (called the photosphere) because they are cooler than other places on the photosphere. Sunspots are the visible "face" of regions where the Sun's magnetic field is very, very strong. These powerful magnetic fields prevent hot plasma in surrounding areas from flowing into sunspots.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseTitle: Sorry, that's not quite right. Try again!
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: Sunspots look darker than the rest of the "surface" of the Sun (called the photosphere) because they are cooler than other places on the photosphere. Sunspots are the visible "face" of regions where the Sun's magnetic field is very, very strong. These powerful magnetic fields prevent hot plasma in surrounding areas from flowing into sunspots.
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseTitle: Close, but not quite. Try again!
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: Sunspots look darker than the rest of the "surface" of the Sun (called the photosphere) because they are cooler than other places on the photosphere. Sunspots are the visible "face" of regions where the Sun's magnetic field is very, very strong. These powerful magnetic fields prevent hot plasma in surrounding areas from flowing into sunspots.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Coronal Loop
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: Coronal loops are extremely hot, with temperatures typically in the range of 2,000,000° to 4,000,000° Celsius (3.6 to 7.2 million degrees Fahrenheit). The loops are made of hot, glowing plasma - essentially an electrically charged gas. The plasma flows along magnetic field lines, akin to the way iron filings align when sprinkled over a horseshoe magnet.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: Coronal loops are hot, bright loops of plasma in the Sun's atmosphere. The lower regions of these loops are "anchored" in the photosphere (the Sun's visible "surface"), which is relatively cool. The loops themselves, however, are much hotter than the photosphere.
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: Coronal loops are hot, bright loops of plasma in the Sun's atmosphere. The lower regions of these loops are "anchored" in the photosphere (the Sun's visible "surface"), which is relatively cool. The loops themselves, however, are much hotter than the photosphere.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Photosphere
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: The photosphere is the visible "surface" of the Sun. Although it is cooler than most other parts of the Sun, it is still very hot by Earthly standards. The temperature of the photosphere is around 5,500° Celsius (about 10,000° Fahrenheit). The Sun's interior, beneath the photosphere is much hotter. Surprisingly, the Sun's atmosphere, above the photosphere, is also mostly much hotter than this "surface" layer.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: The photosphere is the visible "surface" of the Sun. It isn't quite as hot as most other parts of the Sun.
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: The photosphere is the visible "surface" of the Sun. It isn't quite as hot as most other parts of the Sun.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Corona
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: The corona is the upper, outer atmosphere of the Sun. Surprisingly, the corona is very, very hot... much hotter than the "surface" of the Sun (the photosphere). Temperatures in the corona range between 1,000,000° to 3,000,000° Celsius (about 1.8 to 5.4 million degrees Fahrenheit). Although scientists don't fully understand how the corona is heated, they know that energy stored in powerful magnetic fields is converted into heat in the corona.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: The corona is much hotter than a few thousand degrees. This is somewhat surprising, since it is far from the Sun's core where nuclear fusion generates most of the Sun's energy.
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: The corona is actually one of the hottest regions of the Sun. This is somewhat surprising, since it is far from the Sun's core where nuclear fusion generates most of the Sun's energy.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Sun's Core
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: The core, or center, of the Sun is by far the hottest place in our nearby star. Temperatures in the core are nearly 16,000,000° Celsius (more than 28 million degrees Fahrenheit). Nuclear fusion reactions in the core generate the Sun's energy, raising the temperature there to amazing levels.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: The temperature at the Sun's core is very, very high. Nuclear fusion reactions at the center of the Sun generate huge amounts of energy and raise the temperature to an amazingly hot level.
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: The temperature at the Sun's core is very, very high. Nuclear fusion reactions at the center of the Sun generate huge amounts of energy and raise the temperature to an amazingly hot level.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Prominence
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: Prominences have temperatures around 10,000° Celsius (about 18,000° Fahrenheit). Prominences are blobs of hot, glowing plasma - essentially an electrically charged gas. Strong magnetic fields suspend the plasma in the Sun's atmosphere, sometimes for days or weeks at a time.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: Prominences are blobs of hot, glowing plasma - essentially an electrically charged gas. Prominences are hotter than the Sun's "surface" (the photosphere) from which they erupt.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: Prominences are blobs of hot, glowing plasma - essentially an electrically charged gas. Although prominences are quite hot, they aren't among the hottest features on the Sun.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Blast Furnace
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: No, there aren't any blast furnaces on the Sun. We included a blast furnace in this game so you could compare the extremely hot temperatures on the Sun with something very hot on Earth. The temperature inside a blast furnace is between 2,000° and 2,300° Celsius (3,600° to 4,200° Fahrenheit). Although that is crazy hot by Earthly standards, everything on the Sun is even hotter!
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: No, there aren't any blast furnaces on the Sun. We included a blast furnace in this game so you could compare the extremely hot temperatures on the Sun with something very hot on Earth. Although a blast furnace is very hot by Earthly standards, it isn't quite that hot.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: No, there aren't any blast furnaces on the Sun. We included a blast furnace in this game so you could compare the extremely hot temperatures on the Sun with something very hot on Earth. Blast furnaces don't come anywhere close to reaching millions of degrees.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Solar Flare
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: Solar flares have temperatures between about 6,000,000 and 10,000,000° Celsius (around 11 million to 18 million degrees Fahrenheit). These amazing bursts of energy are incredibly hot. A flare appears as a sudden brightening in normal, visible light - as well as in ultraviolet and X-ray wavelengths.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: Although solar flares occur near the relatively cool "surface" of the Sun (the photosphere), these tremendous bursts of energy are actually quite hot.
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseTitle: Almost, but not quite. Try again.
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: Although solar flares occur near the relatively cool "surface" of the Sun (the photosphere), these tremendous bursts of energy are very, very hot.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Filament
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: Filaments have temperatures around 10,000° Celsius (about 18,000° Fahrenheit). Filaments are blobs of hot, glowing plasma - essentially an electrically charged gas. Strong magnetic fields suspend the plasma in the Sun's atmosphere, sometimes for days or weeks at a time. Filaments are actually the same thing as prominences, just viewed from a different angle.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: Filaments are blobs of hot, glowing plasma - essentially an electrically charged gas. Although filaments are quite hot, they aren't among the hottest features on the Sun. Filaments are actually the same thing as prominences, just viewed from a different angle.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseTitle: Almost, but not quite. Try again!
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: Filaments are blobs of hot, glowing plasma - essentially an electrically charged gas. Filaments are hotter than the Sun's "surface" (the photosphere) from which they erupt. Filaments are actually the same thing as prominences, just viewed from a different angle.

DRAGGABLE.TITLE: Spicules
DRAGGABLE.middleResponseBody: Spicules are jets of hot plasma that "leap" upward through the Sun's atmosphere. Spicules have temperatures around 10,000° to 20,000° Celsius (about 18,000° to 36,000° Fahrenheit). The plasma which makes up spicules is essentially an electrically charged gas. Spicules don't last long, typically about 15 minutes. There are usually hundreds of thousands of spicules in the Sun's atmosphere at any given time.
DRAGGABLE.lowerResponseBody: Spicules are jets of hot plasma that "leap" upward through the Sun's atmosphere. Spicules are hotter than the Sun's "surface" (the photosphere) from which they spring forth.
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseTitle: Close, but not quite. Try again!
DRAGGABLE.upperResponseBody: Spicules are jets of hot plasma that "leap" upward through the Sun's atmosphere. Although the plasma in spicules is very hot, it isn't quite that hot.
